awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Vibration Energy Harvesting-Based Sensor System
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to use novel energy harvesting techniques to benefit the expanding wearables market and improve the lives of patients who use prosthetics and orthotics. New integrated circuit technology enables vibration energy harvesting from a physically much smaller vibration harvester. These smaller harvesters enable multiple applications. For example, battery life in wearables to track heart rate and steps walked could be extended. Also, fabric-based vibration energy harvesting applications could be realized in military and first responder uniforms to power communication devices. Similarly, for commercial markets clothing-integrated sensors for digital health applications could be powered by vibration harvesting. Finally, first markets will be explored for vibration harvesting systems integrated in prosthetics or orthotics to improve the quality of life for patients.  A sensor system in orthotics could detect medical complications in patients suffering from diabetic neuropathy.   These new energy harvesting circuits could potentially also power sensors integrated into prosthetics that could identify structural and mechanical problems.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project develops a vibration energy interface circuit that allows cold start-up from record low voltages and low currents using novel CMOS (Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor) design techniques. These CMOS design techniques use only one vibration harvester input to charge large loads such as 100µF capacitors without the use of a transformer or Schottky diodes.  Lowering the minimum start-up voltage in a vibration harvesting interface circuit has been a significant area of circuit research in integrated circuit design over the last decade. The innovation proposed for this SBIR Phase I project uses a classic Cockcroft-Walton charge pump with large off-chip 100µF capacitors. The charge pump's rectification is designed in CMOS to allow leakage-based signals to form and switch the charge pump's rectification from cold start-up. In this project there will be continued research into integrated circuit techniques and solutions to lower the minimum start-up voltage in a circuit interface to a vibration harvester.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Creathadh Energies as a company purses vibration harvested energy applications based on integrated circuit-based IP focusing on a unique method to start-up and harvest low power low voltage vibrations. In Fig. 1 our proposed application is a sensor-based orthotic using energy harvesting that would detect ulcer formation in people with diabetes with the goal of preventing amputation. For this phase I award, the major goal was to focus on the harvester and interface circuit highlighted in Fig. 1. First, a new integrated circuit was designed that improves minimum start-up voltage and start-up time with the goal of creating new IP for Creathadh Energies. Second, an initial piezoelectric harvester would fabricated and tested to illustrate proof of concept and identify problems and areas for improvement in the piezoelectric design. Third, based on customer discovery interviews taking place through both the beat-the-odds boot camp and National I-corps program for NSF recipients and the technical challenges of this project, metrics for the orthotic were further developed and specified. Finally, both the fabricated circuit and piezoelectric harvester were tested together to illustrate the proof of concept for the system to pave the path going forward for a sensor-based orthotic with vibration energy harvesting. Final results show that the output from the piezoelectric harvester is certainly able to charge up Creathadh’s integrated circuit, and a provisional patent was filed based on the circuit research in this award to further strengthen Creathadh’s IP portfolio.

This Small Business Innovation Research grant will dramatically advance vibration energy harvesting technology. The final goal is that the initial use of this novel vibration harvesting technology will deploy a self-powered sensor-based orthotic for detecting diabetic neuropathy. Deploying a sensor-based system using vibration energy harvesting for orthotics will greatly improve the quality of life for diabetic patients by preventing severe foot injury that could lead to the loss of their limbs and potentially lives. Diabetes is especially very challenging for our nation’s veterans and the Department of Veterans Affairs, and this technology will very likely help there. In addition, detection of foot ulcers is an ongoing area of significant research in the podiatry community. Our high functioning sensor-based orthotic that never needs to be recharged will allow previously un-observed events and circumstances to be detected and diagnosed.

More broadly, by enabling an initial market for mass producing piezoelectric harvesters, the innovation developed by this SBIR will bring down the currently prohibitive cost of energy harvesting vibration devices. This reduced price will allow vibration energy harvesting to be used in other industries such as animal tracking, or devices to measure heart rate and other physiological characteristics. As energy harvesting technology advances, robust energy harvesting will initially augment rechargeable batteries, with the potential to eventually replace rechargeable batteries in low current applications. The potential for vibration energy harvesting has broad environmental, societal and military implications.


Last Modified: 01/16/2022
Modified by: James J Mccullagh

Image
  • The proposed product is a sensor-based orthotic to help diabetics sense ulcer formation that could lead to amputation. The phase I award focused on a piezoelectric harvester and a new integrated circuit.
    James McCullagh
